description: Borrowing from Middle French mental, from Late Latin mentālis, from mēns (“mind, disposition; heart, soul”) +‎ -ālis (“-al”, adjectival suffix).

adjectives.description: mental (comparative more mental, superlative most mental)

definitionGroups.group: (relational) Of or relating to the mind or specifically the total emotional and intellectual response of an individual to external reality.

entries.meaning: Of or relating to intellectual as contrasted with emotional activity.
Of, relating to, or being intellectual as contrasted with overt physical activity.
Occurring or experienced in the mind.
Relating to the mind, its activity, or its products as an object of study.
Relating to spirit or idea as opposed to matter.
examples: the distinction between physical things and mental ideas

definitionGroups.group: Of, relating to, or affected by a psychiatric disorder.

entries.meaning: (relational) Intended for the care or treatment of persons affected by psychiatric disorders.
(colloquial, UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, dated in the US, comparable) Mentally disordered; insane, mad, crazy.
examples: He is the most mental freshman I've seen yet.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, comparable) Enjoyable or fun, especially in a frenetic way.
examples: That was a mental party last night.

entries.meaning: Of or relating to telepathic or mind-reading powers.
(anatomy, relational) Of or relating to the chin or median part of the lower jaw, genial.
examples: the mental nerve, the mental region

entries.meaning: (biology, relational) Of or relating to the chinlike or liplike structure.
(zootomy) A plate or scale covering the mentum or chin of a fish or reptile.
